content: The Act may be cited as the "California Reclaimed Water Act for the 21st Century" and includes provisions for coordinating projects and programs. Section 1602 of the Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act is amended to include coordination with the CALFED Bay-Delta Program and compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 for projects under this title. Each project under this title must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATIONS. The Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act is amended to include specific projects and studies. This includes the Castaic Lake Water Agency Reclaimed Water Project. The Secretary may participate in the design, planning, and construction of the Castaic Lake Water Agency reclaimed water project in California, with a federal share of up to 25% of the total cost. Funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for operation or maintenance. $20,000,000 is authorized for this project. Additionally, the Clear Lake Basin Water Reuse Project is also mentioned. The Secretary, in cooperation with Lake County, California, may participate in the design, planning, and construction of the Clear Lake Basin water reuse project to obtain, store, and use reclaimed wastewater for various purposes. The Federal share of the project cost shall not exceed 25%, with funds not to be used for operation or maintenance. $9,000,000 is authorized for this project. The Secretary may provide design and construction assistance for the San Ramon Valley Recycled Water Project in California, with a Federal share not exceeding 25% of the total cost. Funds provided shall not be used for operation or maintenance. $20,000,000 is authorized for this project. Additionally, the Inland Empire Regional Water Recycling Project is also mentioned. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Inland Empire Utilities Agency, may participate in the design, planning, and construction of the Inland Empire regional water recycling project for various public purposes. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25%, with funds not allocated for operation or maintenance. $20,000,000 is authorized for this project. Additionally, the San Pablo Baylands Water Reuse Projects are mentioned in the following section. The Secretary may participate in the San Pablo Baylands water reuse projects with counties in California to use reclaimed wastewater for various purposes. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25%, with funds not for operation or maintenance. $20,000,000 is authorized for this section. The Secretary may provide assistance to California for water recycling projects under the Safe Drinking Water Act, with a federal cost share limit of 25%. Funds cannot be used for project operation or maintenance. $50,000,000 is authorized for this section. SEC. 1638. REGIONAL BRINE LINES. The Secretary may carry out a program under the Federal reclamation laws to assist in constructing regional brine lines in Southern California and the San Francisco Bay area. The Secretary may enter agreements and regulations to construct regional brine lines in the San Francisco Bay area and the Santa Clara Valley area, California. The Federal share of project costs shall not exceed 25% or $50,000,000, and for studies, it shall be 50%. Funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for project operation or maintenance. Authorization of appropriations is granted for these projects. Authorization of Appropriations is granted for this section to carry out necessary activities. Lower Chino Dairy Area Desalination Demonstration and Reclamation Project is authorized for necessary activities. The Secretary, in cooperation with various water agencies, will participate in the design and construction of the Lower Chino Dairy Area desalination project. The Federal share of the project cost will not exceed 25% or $50,000,000. Funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for project operation or maintenance. The Secretary, in cooperation with the WateReuse Foundation, will conduct research on water reuse related to public health, water quality, new technology, salt management, economics, ecosystem restoration, and other important matters. $2,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005 for this program. Additionally, a West Basin Comprehensive Desalination Demonstration Program is established. The Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act is amended to include the West Basin Comprehensive Desalination Demonstration Program in Los Angeles County, California. The Federal government will cover up to 50% of the project costs, but will not fund operation or maintenance. The Federal government will cover up to 50% of the project costs, but will not fund operation or maintenance. Project modifications are addressed in Section 5. The Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act is amended to include the City of Los Angeles Water Recycling Program, which aims to reclaim and reuse wastewater for various public purposes in the Los Angeles area. The project includes the central city project providing recycled water for ecosystem restoration and other uses. The City of Los Angeles Water Recycling Program includes projects such as the central city project for ecosystem restoration and the harbor water recycling project, aiming to provide recycled water for various purposes. The Federal share of the project costs shall not exceed 25 percent, with a maximum limit for the water recycling project. No funds provided by the Secretary can be used for operation or maintenance of the projects. In the San Gabriel Basin, the Federal share of the project authorized by section 1614 is capped at $50,500,000. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act is amended to update various sections related to groundwater study and facilities. The table of contents in the Reclamation Projects Authorization and Adjustment Act of 1992 is amended by inserting a new section after section 1601. The Reclamation Projects Authorization and Adjustment Act of 1992 includes specific projects such as the Willow Lake Natural Treatment System Project, Castaic Lake Water Agency reclaimed water project, Clear Lake Basin water reuse project, San Ramon Valley recycled water project, Inland Empire regional water recycling project, San Pablo Baylands water reuse projects, California water recycling program, Regional brine lines, Lower Chino Dairy Area desalination demonstration and reclamation project, and authorization of appropriations for studies and research on groundwater and water reuse.
